questions.text: The image below shows uptake of various substances during the 0.75 s they are in transit through a pulmonary capillary. Here the Transport of CO is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Diffusion-limited transport means gas uptake is limited by the rate at which the gas diffuses across the alveolar membrane, not by blood flow.
  • Perfusion-limited transport means gas uptake is limited by how quickly blood is flowing through the capillaries.(Option B ruled out)
  • Carbon monoxide (CO) is taken up by hemoglobin in the red blood cells at such a high rate that the partial pressure of CO in the capillaries stays very low and equilibrium is not reached in the 0.75 s the blood is in the pulmonary capillaries. So the CO transfer is diffusion limited.
  • Nitrous oxide (N2O) does not react and reaches equilibrium in about 0.1 s. The amount of N2O taken up is not limited by diffusion but by the amount of blood flowing through the pulmonary capillaries; that is, it is flow-limited.(Option C ruled out)
  • Under normal conditions, O2 is perfusion-limited, but can become diffusion-limited in disease or high altitude.

questions.text: The following is a single breath N2 curve used for measurement of dead space. What is Phase II in this curve for?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The single breath N2 curve is used to measure the dead space in an individual.
  • From mid-inspiration, the patient takes as deep a breath as possible of pure O2, then exhales steadily while the N2 content of the expired gas is continuously measured, and plotted in the graph.
  • It comprises 4 phases.
    • Phase 1: The initial gas exhaled having only pure oxygen but no nitrogen.(Option B ruled out)
    • Phase II: It contains a mixture of dead space and alveolar gas.
    • Phase III: It contains only alveolar gas(Option A ruled out)
    • Phase IV: N2 content of expired gas is increased.
  • The volume of the dead space is the volume of the gas expired from peak inspiration to the midportion of phase II.

questions.text: Among the following, which is the best option to define the air present in the conducting zone of the respiratory tract and also in the non-perfused alveoli?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The dead space air is the air that does not take part in exchange of gases between atmosphere and blood.
  • It is of 3 types
    • Anatomical dead space: It refers to the volume of air in the respiratory tract (nose, trachea, bronchi, bronchioles) that does not participate in gas exchange because it does not reach the alveoli.(Option A ruled out)
    • It is approximately equal to the body weight in pounds. (approx. 150 ml)
    • Alveolar dead space air:It refers to the air which does not take part in gas exchange due to non perfusion.(Option C ruled out)
    • Physiological dead space air:It refers to the sum total of anatomical and alveolar dead space air.
    • In healthy individuals, the two dead spaces are identical.
  • In disease states, no exchange may take place between the gas in some of the alveoli and the blood, and some of the alveoli may be over ventilated. Two dead spaces are not identical in diseased state.

Key takeaways:

  • Physiological dead space air:It refers to the sum total of anatomical and alveolar dead space air.

questions.text: Following is a graph of ventilation perfusion ratio in a 36-year-old male patient. If on this graph Va/Q found is higher than the normal. What could be the probable causes for it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In normal conditions if ventilation to the alveolus and perfusion to the alveolus is adequate Va/Q is 0.8 to 1.
  • In conditions where the perfusion has been decreased as marked with an arrow the Va/Q is more than normal.
  • In conditions where the ventilation to the alveolus is decreased (increase in physiological dead space) Va/Q is less than normal.
  • In emphysema, destruction of alveolar walls leads to loss of capillaries, reducing perfusion (↓Q).Some alveoli are well-ventilated but poorly perfused → ↑ V/Q.This contributes to wasted ventilation (dead space).(Option A ruled out)
  • Pulmonary Embolism(PE) causes acute obstruction of pulmonary arteries which causes perfusion drop drastically in affected regions. Alveoli may still be ventilated causing a very high V/Q ratio.(Option B ruled out)
  • In fibrosis, thickened alveolar walls impair gas exchange, and fibrosis may destroy capillaries, reducing perfusion causing the same ↑ V/Q ratio in such zones.(Option C ruled out)
  • Causes of alteration in Va/Q ratio:
    • Uneven alveolar ventilation:
      • Bronchial asthma, emphysema
      • Pulmonary fibrosis, pneumothorax
      • Congestive cardiac failure
    • Uneven pulmonary perfusion:
      • Anatomical shunts e.g. Fallot's tetralogy
      • Pulmonary embolism
      • emphysema
      • Pulmonary fibrosis,CCF

questions.text: What is the difference between Pulmonary circulation and systemic circulation ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acute hypoxia causes pulmonary vasoconstriction (HPV) and chronic hypoxia causes pulmonary hypertension, whereas hypoxia causes systemic vasodilation.
  • HPV is a homeostatic mechanism that diverts desaturated, mixed venous blood in the pulmonary artery from poorly ventilated (hypoxic) areas of the lungs to other better ventilated (normoxic) areas of the lungs.
  • Characteristics of pulmonary circulation are
    • low pressure
    • low resistance(Option B ruled out)
    • high capacitance system(Option C ruled out)
  • Characteristic of systemic circulation are
    • High pressure
    • High resistance
    • Low capacitance
  • Pulmonary vessels have higher compliance because Pulmonary arteries and their branches are thin walled and distensible. It means that it can accommodate changes in blood volume without a significant increase in pressure.
  • In Pulmonary circulation the right heart has to work against only pulmonary vessels which is comparatively a smaller network. It has low pressure and low resistance circulation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Acute hypoxia causes pulmonary vasoconstriction (HPV) and chronic hypoxia causes pulmonary hypertension, whereas hypoxia causes systemic vasodilation.

questions.text: A 54 year old female visited the doctor for headache and breathlessness on exertion. On investigation the doctor found that the patient is having circulatory hypoxia. Which of the following mechanisms help to adapt in stagnant(circulatory) hypoxia by releasing more oxygen from hemoglobin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Stagnant (Circulatory) Hypoxia occurs when blood flow to tissues is reduced, but the oxygen content of blood is normal. It is seen in heart failure, shock, or local vascular obstruction. The tissues get less O2 delivery due to slow circulation.
  • To manage this reduced O2 delivery, the body adapts by facilitating more oxygen release from hemoglobin in tissues.
  • This is done by increasing the 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG), it binds to deoxygenated hemoglobin, decreasing hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen.
  • This causes a rightward shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve thus resulting in more O2 released to tissues.

Explanation of other options:

  • Increased pH(Option A): It causes Alkalosis (↑pH) shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to the left resulting in less O2 released from hemoglobin.
  • Decreased CO2(Option B): It leads to respiratory alkalosis causing leftward shift resulting in hemoglobin holding onto oxygen.
  • Decreased temperature(Option D): It lowers metabolic rate and increases hemoglobin's O2 affinity → less release to tissues.

questions.text: Among the following, which type of oxygen binding compound has maximum affinity for oxygen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Myoglobin resembles hemoglobin but binds 1 rather than 4 mol of O2 per mole protein. Myoglobin also has greater affinity for O2 than hemoglobin thus it can release O2 in muscle when PO2 in blood is low especially during exercise. The Hb-O2 dissociation curve shifts to the left.
  • Normally Fe++ (ferrous ion) is present in the hemoglobin compound. On exposure to certain drugs or oxidizing agents Fe++(ferrous) is converted into Fe+++ (ferric ion). Ferric ions have less affinity for oxygen. Presence of Fe+++ forms methemoglobin which cannot bind O2 effectively, thus causing functional anemia.It has very poor or essentially no oxygen-carrying capacity.(Option D ruled out)
  • In adult hemoglobin Hb has 2alpha and 2 beta chains. In fetal hemoglobin there are 2alpha and 2 gamma chains in hemoglobin. Fetal Hb (Hb F) has higher affinity for oxygen than adult Hb but lower than myoglobin.(Option B and Option A ruled out)

questions.text: P50 is partial pressure at 50% hemoglobin saturation with oxygen. Which factor/s from the list does not cause an increase in P50?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • P50 is the partial pressure of o2 that produces a 50% saturation of the Hb with o2 Normal P50 for arterial blood at 37°C body temperature and at pCO2 of blood 40 mmhg is 25-27 mmhg.Hb affinity for o2 is inversely related to the p50
  • 2,3-DPG is abundant in red cells. It is formed from 3- phosphoglyceraldehyde, which is a product of glycolysis via the Embden- Meyerhof pathway. It binds to beta chains in deoxygenated haemoglobin and reduces the affinity for haemoglobin with oxygen.
  • At equilibrium, an increase in the concentration of 2,3-DPG shifts the Hb-O2 dissociation curve to the right, causing more O2 to be liberated.
  • Acidosis inhibits red cell glycolysis, the 2,3-DPG concentration falls when the pH is low. It causes a decrease in P50.
  • Thyroid hormones, androgens, growth hormones, exercise, rise in temperature causes increase in P50due to increase in 2-3 DPG conc.(Option B, Option C ruled out)

Bound to the iron of heme group of hemoglobin

questions.text: Carbon dioxide is transported in the blood through different mechanisms . Which of the following mechanisms is incorrect regarding CO2 transport in the blood?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • CO2 is transported in the blood from tissues to the lungs by the following ways:
    • In dissolved state: 7% (0.3 ml / 100 ml). Solubility of CO2 is 20 times higher than O2. SO, more CO2 than O2 is present in a simple solution at equal partial pressures.(Option A ruled out)
    • In the form of bicarbonate ion- 70% (2.5 ml/ 100 ml). It occurs via chloride and reverse chloride shift with anion exchangers.(Option B ruled out)
    • In combination with Hb and plasma proteins - 23% (1.5 ml / 100 ml) Here When CO2 binds to hemoglobin it binds to globin components or other proteins and forms carbamino compounds. Oxygen binds to the heme portion of hemoglobin. In heme portion the central Fe++ ion is the binding site for oxygen.(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 37-year-old man was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He is conscious but exhibits rapid, shallow breathing with a respiratory rate of 30/min and a tidal volume of 250 mL per breath on spirometry. CT imaging reveals a small contusion involving the upper pons. Which of the following respiratory centers is most likely affected in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario the patient is having rapid and shallow breathing and his CT scan reports a contusion over the upper pons.
  • This indicates Pneumotaxic centre hyperactivity, as the inspirations are prematurely terminated.
  • Pneumotaxic Center (in the upper pons):
    • It inhibits inspiration by acting on the dorsal respiratory group (DRG) in the medulla and limits tidal volume, leading to shorter inspiratory duration, thus increasing respiratory rate.

Explanation of other options:

  • Dorsal respiratory group(Option A)- mainly causes normal respiration. In it normal inspiration is an active process while normal expiration is a passive process.
  • Ventral respiratory group(Option B)- It functions in both inspiration and expiration. Totally inactive during normal quiet breathing. It operates during overdrive mechanism.
  • Apneustic center(Option C)- Resulting in deeper and prolonged inspiratory effort which is called "apneusis".Normally inhibited by the pneumotaxic centre and by the vagus nerve.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Below 70mmHg PO2 Peripheral chemoreceptor respond via increase in respiratory activity
The central chemoreceptor suppresses the peripheral chemoreceptor area
It occurs due to decrease in stimulation of central chemoreceptors due to fall in PCO2 after some time
All of the above are true

questions.text: In a clinical case if a patient with respiratory disorder has arterial PO2 of around 70 mmhg. Normal arterial PO2 is 95 mmhg. Even if PO2 is low in this patient after sometime when respiratory activity is observed it is found normal why?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In chronic hypoxia with associated low PCO2 due to hyperventilation, the central chemoreceptors adapt and reduce their excitatory drive, leading to normalization of ventilation.
  • Initial Phase:
    • Low PO2 (~70 mmHg) triggers peripheral chemoreceptors (carotid bodies) → increases respiration.
    • Hyperventilation → leads to decreased arterial PCO2.
  • Secondary Phase:
    • Central chemoreceptors, which respond to increased PCO2 (via CSF pH drop), lose their drive as PCO2 falls.
    • This reduces the overall respiratory drive, even if PO2 remains low.(Option A ruled out)
  • Peripheral chemoreceptor stimulation is weaker than central chemoreceptor drive, so breathing normalizes.
  • The central chemoreceptor does not have direct control over the peripheral chemoreceptor area.(Option B ruled out)

KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: A 47-year-old cancer patient is suffering from severe pain. He was prescribed opioids to relieve pain. As a side effect respiration is inhibited in this patient. Which receptor agonists/ antagonists will be helpful to reduce this side effect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • 5HT4 receptors are present on the prebotzinger complex. 5HT4 agonists reduce the effect of respiratory inhibition occurring due to opioid analgesics. Thus administration of 5HT4 is helpful in this case.
  • Neurons in the prebotzinger complex are rhythm generators for respiration. They are present in the medulla.
  • There are NK1 receptors and μ-opioid receptors on these neurons also.
  • μ-opioid receptors are stimulated via opioid analgesics like morphine, pethidine. These drugs are used to alleviate the severe pain in terminal disease.
  • By blocking μ-opioid receptors these drugs are of no use as the effect of pain relief is nullified.(Option A and Option B ruled out)
  • 5HT4 receptor antagonist does not solve the problem as it further reduces the respiration.(Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • 5HT4 receptors are present on the prebotzinger complex. When 5HT4 agonists are given it reduces the effect of respiratory inhibition occurring due to opioid analgesics.

When stimulated it increases respiratory depth

questions.text: A 43-year-old male visited the physician as he was not able to exercise. When he does moderate exercise, he becomes hypoxic. On investigation the doctor found that his ventral respiratory group of neurons are not functioning. Which of the following functions is affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ventral respiratory group of neurons operates more or less as an overdrive mechanism when high levels of pulmonary ventilation are required, especially during moderate to heavy exercise.
  • The Dorsal respiratory group of neurons controls normal tidal inspiration and respiratory rhythm. Normal expiration is a passive process that occurs due to elastic recoil of lungs.(Option B ruled out)
  • Apneustic center when stimulated resulting in deeper and prolonged inspiratory effort which is called "apneusis".(Option C and Option D ruled out)
  • Normally the apneustic center is inhibited by the pneumotaxic center and by the vagus nerve.
  • The primary effect of the pneumotaxic center is to limit inspiration (shallow) and the secondary effect is to increase the rate of breathing.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: The glomus cells present in the carotid and aortic bodies are excited by hypoxia due to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The type I glomus cells in carotid and aortic bodies have dense core granules that contain catecholamines.
  • The principal transmitter appears to be dopamine, which excites the nerve endings by way of D2 receptors.
  • When exposed to hypoxia or cyanide these receptors inhibit the O2 sensitive K+ channels present in the membrane of type I glomus cells.
  • It causes release of dopamine neurotransmitter that excites the carotid sinus nerve. They are fibers in the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Explanation of other options:

  • Excitation/Inhibition of O2-sensitive Na+ channels(Option A & Option C):There are no known O2-sensitive Na+ channels involved in glomus cell oxygen sensing.The depolarization that triggers neurotransmitter release comes from reduced K+ efflux, not from increased Na+ influx via O2-sensitive channels.
  • Excitation of O2-sensitive K+ channels(Option B):The opposite occurs during hypoxia ,it inhibits (closes) O2-sensitive K+ channels.

choices.text: When amount of dissolved O2 is less
When the blood flow to the receptor is reduced

questions.text: The receptors in the carotid and aortic body are stimulated by which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In glomus cells O2 needs of the cells can be met largely by dissolved O2 alone, because the blood flow to carotid and aortic bodies is 2000 ml/100 gm of tissue /minute (total weight= 2mg). It is very high compared to even the brain (420ml/100gm/minute).
  • Oxygen requirements of these bodies are met with only dissolved oxygen.
  • When dissolved oxygen is less they are stimulated. The receptors are not stimulated in conditions such as anemia or carbon monoxide poisoning, in which the amount of dissolved O2 in the blood reaching the receptors is generally normal, even though the combined O2 in the blood is markedly decreased.(Option A ruled out)
  • In vascular stasis when arterial PO2 is low, the amount of oxygen delivered to it is less, so it responds to vascular stasis.(Option B ruled out)
  • Cyanide prevents O2 utilization at tissue level providing powerful stimulation of these receptors.(Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The receptors in the carotid and aortic body are stimulated by -
    • When amount of dissolved O2 is less
    • When the blood flow to the receptor is reduced
    • When exposed to cyanide

questions.text: The chemoreceptors present in the brain stem do not respond to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • There are two types of chemoreceptors
    • Central chemoreceptors present in the brainstem
    • Peripheral chemoreceptors present in carotid and aortic bodies
  • Peripheral chemoreceptors respond to
    • High PCO2
    • Low PO2
    • Increase in H+
  • Central chemoreceptors respond to

questions.text: A healthy individual is undergoing a respiratory physiology experiment. When the lungs are steadily inflated beyond normal tidal volumes, the respiratory cycle is altered, resulting in prolonged expiration. Which of the following reflexes best explains this response?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Hering-Breuer inflation reflex is a protective pulmonary reflex that comes into play when the lungs are overinflated typically during deep or prolonged inspiration. This reflex is mediated by slowly adapting stretch receptors (SARs) in the airway smooth muscle.These receptors send signals via the vagus nerve to the respiratory centers in the medulla.This leads to inhibition of further inspiration and prolongation of expiration

Explanation of other options:

  • Bezold-Jarisch reflex(Option A)A cardiovascular reflex triggered by ventricular stretch or chemical stimuli, causing bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea, not related to lung inflation.
  • Pulmonary chemoreflex(Option C)Elicited by chemical irritants in the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction, apnea, and coughing, not prolonged expiration.
  • Hering-Breuer deflation reflex(Option D)Triggered by sudden lung deflation, it leads to increased inspiratory effort, the opposite of what's described.

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: Vagal stimulation by massaging the neck region(carotid sinus massage)

questions.text: A 17-year-old male had hiccups which produced discomfort sometimes. Which of the following interventions can reduce or stop the hiccup episode?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hiccup is a spasmodic contraction of diaphragm and other inspiratory muscles that produces an inspiration during which the glottis suddenly closes.
  • The glottic closure is responsible for the characteristic sensation and sound.
  • Breath holding will increase CO2 levels → inhibits the hiccup reflex arc. This is a common non-pharmacological method.(Option A ruled out)
  • Vagal stimulation by giving carotid sinus massage stimulates vagal afferents (like carotid sinus massage or pharyngeal stimulation), which can interrupt the hiccup reflex arc.(Option B ruled out)
  • Dopamine antagonist drugs like chlorpromazine, metoclopramide, and haloperidol have been used to treat persistent hiccups. They act on central dopaminergic pathways thought to be involved in the hiccup reflex.(Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department in respiratory distress following a suspected suicide attempt. Her relatives are unaware of the exact cause, but clinical suspicion of poisoning is high. Despite administration of 100% oxygen under hyperbaric conditions (3 atmospheres), her condition does not improve. Which type of hypoxia is most likely responsible for her unresponsiveness to oxygen therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario discussed is a case of cyanide poisoning, which causes Histotoxic hypoxia, a type in which the tissue is unable to utilize oxygen even if adequately present.
  • Cyanide binds to cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV) in the mitochondrial electron transport chain and inhibits oxidative phosphorylation, blocking ATP production and causing lactic acidosis due to anaerobic respiration.
  • Treatment for cyanide poisoning:
    • Amyl nitrite / Sodium nitrite induces methemoglobin to bind cyanide forming cyanmethemoglobin thus removing cyanide from mitochondria.
    • Sodium thiosulfate converts cyanide to thiocyanate which is non toxic and excreted by kidneys.
    • Hydroxocobalamin : It binds cyanide directly → cyanocobalamin and excreted in urine
  • Hypoxia is defined as a condition in which there is inadequate oxygen supply to the tissues to meet their metabolic demands.It can be due to:
    • Oxygen delivery is compromised (e.g., anemia, ischemia)
    • Tissues are unable to utilize oxygen (e.g., cyanide poisoning)

Types of Hypoxia with Example:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is relocated from Gujarat to Gangtok due to job transfer. After a week at Gangtok he was having headaches with nausea and multiple episodes of vomiting; later, he developed an episode of seizures. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • When a person rapidly ascends to high altitude (typically above 2,500-3,000 m), especially from a low-altitude region like Gujarat, the body doesn't have enough time to acclimatize. This can result in altitude-related illnesses like:
    • Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS)
    • High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE)
    • High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE)
  • Above mentioned symptoms are due to cerebral edema which occurred due to low PO2 at high altitude which causes systemic arteriolar dilation(Option A ruled out), and if cerebral autoregulation does not compensate, there is an increase in capillary pressure that favors increased transudation of fluid into brain tissue. It causes cerebral edema.
  • It is a life threatening condition and immediate descent to ground level is advised. Then the patient will be treated with oxygen therapy.
  • Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS):A mild form of altitude illness characterized by headache, nausea, fatigue, and sleep disturbances within 6–24 hours of ascent above 2,500 m.
  • High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE):A life-threatening condition marked by fluid accumulation in the lungs due to hypoxia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction, presenting with breathlessness, cough, and cyanosis at high altitudes.
  • Hyperventilation is seen as a compensatory response in high altitude, due to decrease in partial pressure of oxygen.(Option C and Option D ruled out)

Key takeaway:

  • Cerebral edema at high altitude occurs due to-Low PO2 at high altitude causes systemic arteriolar dilation, and if cerebral autoregulation does not compensate, there is an increase in capillary pressure that favors increased transudation of fluid into brain tissue.

choices.text: It is made up of 3 subunits (alpha, beta, gamma)
In hypoxia alpha subunits are ubiquitinated rapidly
In hypoxia alpha subunit dimerizes with beta subunits of HIF
Gamma subunit is responsible to activate the genes to respond to hypoxia

questions.text: In response to hypoxia the body activates a transcriptional mechanism mediated by hypoxia inducible factors.Which of the following statements regarding HIF is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • HIF is a transcription factor activated under low oxygen conditions (hypoxia).
  • It is made up of 2 subunits only:(Option A ruled out)
    • HIF-α (oxygen-sensitive)
    • HIF-β (also known as ARNT - Aryl hydrocarbon receptor nuclear translocator)
  • In normoxia:
    • HIF-α is hydroxylated → binds to von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) protein → undergoes ubiquitination → degraded in proteasomes.(Option B ruled out)
  • In hypoxia:
    • Hydroxylation is inhibited → HIF-α is stabilized, enters the nucleus, and dimerizes with HIF-β.
    • The HIF-α/β complex binds to hypoxia-response elements (HREs) in DNA and activates transcription of genes involved in adaptation to hypoxia (e.g., erythropoietin, VEGF, glycolytic enzymes).(Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant with a history of prolonged oxygen therapy, including intermittent use of hyperbaric oxygen therapy for severe hypoxia is being monitored for complications. Which of the following is/are recognized adverse effects of prolonged high-concentration oxygen therapy in infants?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Administering oxygen hyperbaric or 100 % is a very helpful treatment in varieties of hypoxia.
  • But long-term administration can produce reactive oxygen species including superoxide anion (O2-) and H2O2.
  • Retrolental fibroplasia (now called Retinopathy of Prematurity : ROP)is seen in preterm infants receiving high O2 concentrations.(Option A ruled out)
  • Oxygen causes vasoconstriction of retinal vessels followed by abnormal neovascularization, which may lead to retinal detachment and blindness.
  • Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD)is a chronic lung disease of infancy caused by prolonged oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation.(Option B ruled out)
  • Leads to alveolar simplification, interstitial fibrosis, and long-term respiratory issues.
  • Administration of 100% O2 at increased pressure accelerates the onset of O2 toxicity, with tracheobronchial irritation.(Option C ruled out)

Key takeaway:

  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy for around more than two weeks increases risk of-
    • Retrolental fibroplasia
    • Bronchopulmonary dysplasia
    • Tracheobronchial irritation

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a recurrent stroke after he was found unconscious by his neighbour on the floor of his apartment. He has a history of cerebrovascular disease. On examination, he was found to have an unusual breathing pattern. Which of the following breathing patterns have prolonged inspiratory spasms that resemble breath-holding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Apneustic breathing is characterized by prolonged inspiratory spasms followed by inadequate expiratory effort, resembling breath-holding.

  • It is caused by damage to the pons, particularly the lower pons or pontine tegmentum, often due to stroke or trauma.
  • In this case, the patient's history of cerebrovascular disease and recurrent stroke suggests brainstem involvement, making apneustic breathing the most likely pattern.

Abnormal Breathing Patterns
